message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing an acute asthma attack and needs quick relief. Inhaled albuterol is a short-acting bronchodilator that can provide quick relief by relaxing the airway smooth muscles. Inhaled fluticasone is a preventer inhaler that takes time to build up and is not useful for quick relief. Inhaled cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer that can prevent symptoms but is not useful in an acute attack. Oral montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that can prevent symptoms but is also not useful in an acute attack.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inhaled albuterol is a short-acting bronchodilator used for quick relief of bronchial asthma symptoms. This patient is experiencing difficulty breathing and bilateral wheezing, so the most appropriate option for quick relief would be inhaled albuterol. Inhaled fluticasone is a long-acting corticosteroid used for the prevention of asthma symptoms, but it would not provide immediate relief in this acute situation. Inhaled cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used for the prevention of asthma symptoms, and oral montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used for the prevention of asthma symptoms. Neither option is used for quick relief of acute asthma symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has acute exacerbation of asthma with bilateral wheezing, and albuterol is a short-acting beta-agonist that can provide quick relief in such situations. Fluticasone is a long-acting corticosteroid that is used as a preventer inhaler, not for quick relief. Cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer that prevents asthma symptoms but is not used for quick relief. Montelukast is a leukotriene-receptor antagonist that is used for maintenance of asthma control, not for quick relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inhaled albuterol is a short-acting bronchodilator that provides quick relief of asthma symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, and coughing. Inhaled fluticasone is a corticosteroid that is used as a preventive inhaler and only provides long-term control of asthma symptoms. Inhaled cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer that prevents asthma attacks but doesn't provide quick relief. Oral montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that also helps prevent asthma attacks but doesn't provide quick relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inhaled albuterol is a quick-relief bronchodilator medication that works within minutes to relieve asthma symptoms. Inhaled fluticasone is a long-term control medication that takes several days of regular use to become effective. Inhaled cromolyn is a preventive medication that takes several weeks to become effective. Oral montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that is used for long-term asthma control but takes several hours to become effective.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Albuterol is a short-acting beta agonist that provides quick relief by relaxing the bronchial smooth muscles. Fluticasone is a long-acting corticosteroid that is used for daily maintenance treatment of asthma, and it does not provide quick relief. Cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer that is used for prevention of asthma symptoms and does not provide quick relief. Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that is used for prevention of asthma symptoms and does not provide quick relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Albuterol is a short-acting beta2-agonist and is used as a rescue medication in asthma attacks. Fluticasone is a corticosteroid and is used for long-term control of asthma. Cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer and is used for prophylaxis of asthma attacks. Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist and is also used for long-term control of asthma, but it is not as effective for acute asthma attacks. Therefore, in this scenario, inhaled albuterol is the most likely medication to provide quick relief for the patient's acute asthma attack.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inhaled albuterol is a short-acting bronchodilator that can quickly relieve asthma symptoms, while inhaled fluticasone is a long-acting controller medication that helps prevent symptoms but does not provide quick relief. Inhaled cromolyn is another controller medication that works by stabilizing mast cells in the lungs and preventing the release of inflammatory chemicals, but it does not provide quick relief. Oral montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that can help prevent and relieve asthma symptoms, but it is not as fast-acting as inhaled albuterol.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Albuterol is a quick-acting bronchodilator used to relieve acute asthma symptoms by relaxing the muscles in the airways, making it easier to breathe. Fluticasone is a long-acting corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation and prevent asthma symptoms, but it does not provide quick relief. Cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to prevent allergic reactions, and montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used as a maintenance therapy for asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inhaled albuterol is a short-acting beta-2 agonist that quickly relieves bronchoconstriction and can be used in acute asthma attacks. Inhaled fluticasone is a corticosteroid used for preventing asthma attacks and does not provide immediate relief. Inhaled cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used for preventing asthma attacks and does not provide immediate relief. Oral montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used for preventing asthma attacks and does not provide immediate relief.
